Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Multi-dimensional Scheduling and Resource Allocation in Data Centers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data centers and cluster computing platforms have become the dominant computational paradigms of the past decade, becoming the de facto method of executing Big Data workloads. Typically, the entire cluster is treated as a set of resources shared by multiple clients who submit jobs requiring different types of resources. To add to this heterogeneity (or dimensionality) in resource requirements, machines in a cluster can be heterogeneous in terms of resources they provide. In such settings, resources need to be allocated and priced appropriately so as to balance performance with demand.

In this project, the PIs seek to study job scheduling in data centers to optimize temporal Quality of Service metrics such as response time along with fairness, when jobs can have resource requirements that are multi-dimensional. The main question studied can be phrased as: How does the temporal nature of job scheduling interplay with the dimensionality of resource requirements, and how do these two in turn interact with the classical economic desiderata of incentives and fairness?

This project is differentiated from previous work in aiming to develop appropriate models and algorithms through the lens of theoretical computer science, particularly by a fusion of the disparate fields of approximation and online algorithms, algorithmic game theory, and stochastic optimization. The resulting insights will be used to also develop new techniques to address classical scheduling and game theoretic problems that have defied successful solutions. The project is interdisciplinary, and the theoretical models and techniques developed will be motivated by the application domain of new hardware architectures stemming from emerging technologies, and the heterogeneity arising from provisioning them within a data center. Further, empirical validations will be performed, both via simulation on traces from data center executions, as well as deployment and experiments on clusters. This will ultimately influence the design and deployment of internet systems that use and generate massive data.

The interdisciplinary nature of the project points to not only the need for training a pipeline of students from high school students to graduates and imparting to them the power of algorithmic thinking and its broader relevance, but also the necessity for bringing scientists, mathematicians, and system builders to the same platform for active exchange of ideas. Towards this end, the PIs seek to equip the next generation of students, including women and minorities, with the relevant algorithmic skills by an education plan that includes effective teaching and mentorship, as well as to broadly disseminate the proposed work by organizing workshops and by writing books and surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.  This project focused on resource allocation and scheduling problems in data centers and multicore architectures when jobs obtain speedup from multiple resources. The agenda has three components: Reasoning about fairness and game-theoretic aspects of such resource allocation, developing a theoretical understanding of pricing schemes under various scheduling constraints, and finally, the question of scheduling when job arrivals and lengths are unknown, and when decisions need to be decentralized. Our work focused on a mix of theoretical questions, as well as concrete applications to the domain of computer architecture. Themes that cuts across our work is reasoning about dynamics of jobs and resources, being robust to uncertainty about the future, and game-theoretic ways of reasoning about resource allocations.

Intellectual Merit. We present the key research highlights of our work. In the realm of scheduling, we present a general model and the first provable algorithms for optimizing delay in the online non-clairvoyant setting (that is, when jobs have unknown lengths and arrival times) when obtain speedup from multiple resources. In addition, we developed a game-theoretic multi-agent framework along with theoretical and empirical findings, for the problems of sharing power in a computing system such as multicore architecture, as well as co-locating jobs in a data center. 

In the realm of fairness, our work presents the first algorithms for the problem of fairly allocating resources to jobs under the constraint that the allocations should not change much when new jobs arrive or existing jobs depart. We also presented a simple algorithm along with theoretical analysis for the problem of achieving long-term fairness in allocations between jobs, when these jobs have requirements that change temporally and unpredictably. We also present a general model of fairness and associated algorithms when jobs derive shared utility from resources provisioned, for instance, in a shared cache system.  

Finally, in the realm of pricing resources, our work presented the first provable and computationally efficient auctions for maximizing seller’s revenue when the buyer is interested in multiple items but have limited budgets. We also presented the first provable algorithms for pricing items to a stream of buyers, when the items are transient and expire at an unknown time in the future. All these works have appeared in the leading conferences in theoretical computer science, computational economics, and computer architecture.

Broader Impacts. In addition to intellectual contributions to the field of theoretical computer science and computer architecture, our work draws inspiration and contributes to the algorithmic study of auctions and fairness, topics that has largely been in the realm of Economics and Social Science respectively.  In addition, we have infused these insights into the development of decentralized primitives for job location and power sharing in modern multi-core computer architectures. In addition to curricular improvements such as developing a new course on Algorithmic Decision Making, the PIs have developed and co-organized workshops at the Simons Institute of Theoretical Computer Science, and the ACM EC conference. They have supervised several graduate and undergraduate students (including female students) as part of this grant. These students have won best thesis awards at Duke, best paper awards at leading conferences, and mentions at the CRA outstanding undergraduate researcher award. We have also supervised high school students leading to published papers in leading conferences.
